Ada Lovelace developed the first piece of software in history, for Charles Babbage‚Äôs early mechanical general-purpose computer, the analytical engine; she‚Äôs, therefore, the world‚Äôs first software programmer! Today is Ada Lovelace Day and we are celebrating women in technological fields.

Here at Altlab we have a strong feminine influence since two of our founders are awesomely extraordinary techy women!

Catarina Mota

Catarina is a bit our de facto leader, gluing us all together with her incredible tenderness and forced volunteering skills. Her main interests and topics of research are computer vision, intelligent materials, hackerspaces and personal fabrication. Catarina got her Master degree in New York University‚Äôs Interactive Telecommunications Program where she specialized in physical computing and interactive installations. Besides AltLab, she‚Äôs one of the founders and main writters of http://openmaterials.org/. She‚Äôs also an active member of Thingiverse and her ‚Äúthings‚Äù and procedural 3d modelling are praised by just about everyone, check it out http://www.thingiverse.com/catarina!

M√≥nica Mendes

M√≥nica (the blonde acrobatic monkey suit) is our charming radical surfer founder! When she‚Äôs not hacking her own Range Rover she‚Äôs busy working with real-time video installations on a project called RTiVISS http://www.rtiviss.com/ which is the basis of her PhD. She is also an interface designer and a multimedia educator.

item.content:encoded:
‚Ä¶Don‚Äôt let others tell you how many buttons you can press at once, these are times of freedom

This is a homemade game-pad with just one accelerometer (a breakout board from Sparkfun) and one push-button.

Using a simple, custom protocol and a C# listener we could play Acceleroids, an Asteroids lost sibling on Steroids, which uses the accelerometer to control the ship and the button to shoot.

next steps will be to turn this into a generic game-pad by simulating keyboard key presses for any sensor you throw at the Arduino, allowing you to create truly funky pads to control your favourite game. Stay tuned!

Edit: We were alerted by friendly comments that this project resembles another project/tutorial that can be found here: http://lusorobotica.com/index.php/topic,902.0.html
